articles.title: ICEMAN A BIG BOOSTER OF ARENA ACTIVITIES
articles.summary: Until his 2025 retirement from official duties after 13 years, Fawcett area farmer Gordon McCann oversaw shinny games and hockey practices and maintained the ice at the Fawcett Community Hall and Arena. Its schedule now includes men’s and children’s leagues, and its two curling sheets are central to the community’s annual cabaret and bonspiel to be held this year in late January. Nicknamed Iceman McCann by young skaters, he continues to take on occasional volunteer arena activities and will fiel

articles.title: FOREVER IN ROTATION
articles.summary: On Tim van der Hoek’s irrigated acres near Vauxhall, potatoes, seed canola and sugar beets are central to the bottom line, but CWRS and durum also play a key role. In fact, cereals reliably hold his high-value rotation together. Of his more than 3,000 acres, much is rented, all is irrigated. Potatoes and sugar beets are grown once every five years while cereals or corn fill out the balance. The cereal years can be the thinnest on the balance sheet, but they are essential to the good health of hi

articles.title: QUALITY IS JOB ONE
articles.summary: Established in 1948, the Brewing and Malting Barley Research Institute (BMBRI) has endured and largely maintained its initial mandate to improve Canadian malting barley top to bottom. This is achieved as the organization secures research grants, conducts quality evaluation of malting barley and disseminates information on the crop.

articles.title: A GOLDEN MARKET INDICATOR
articles.summary: The relative value of gold to other commodities, including wheat, is at an all-time high. For example, one ounce of gold was worth almost 72 barrels of oil at the end of November 2025, up from 7.4 barrels in the same month of 2020. Over the same period, an ounce of gold went from being worth about 100 bushels of wheat to 750. What does this inverse relationship indicate?

articles.title: EXPORT SALES DATA NEEDED
articles.summary: Canada’s grain sector runs on global demand. Farmers seed, harvest, store and market their crops into a world shaped by forces beyond the farm. Markets move quickly, buyers adjust accordingly and price signals shift with little warning. Despite this, Canada continues to operate without one of the essential tool of timely export sales reporting.

articles.title: DURUM MARKET A WORK IN PROGRESS
articles.summary: Noodles have been a treasured food staple in China for nearly 4,000 years, but recent demand for high-quality pasta has grown. According to the World Instant Noodles Association, China was the world’s largest instant noodle consumer at 43.8 billion servings in 2024. Over the last decade, however, a shift has taken place as pasta has been adopted alongside traditional noodles and gained market share. Trade experts agree this shift has the potential to hugely impact CWAD exports.

articles.title: SEE THE FIELD IN A NEW WAY
articles.summary: On the Olds College Smart Farm, data is rolling in from an ongoing research project that utilizes the Raven Augmenta Field Analyzer. This camera vision machine learning technology senses crop conditions using digital imagery to adjust input application during field operations. Unlike current methods that rely on pre-determined maps, the camera uses an algorithm to make instantaneous decisions about the rate of inputs to apply on crops.

articles.title: BARLEY BOUNCES BACK
articles.summary: In contrast with the previous year, farmers across Western Canada produced an exceptional crop of malting barley in 2025. Strong yields, consistent quality and competitive pricing signals have drawn interest from major brewers and maltsters across multiple markets. The crop gives Canada a solid supply position as customers prepare their 2026 malting and brewing schedules.

articles.title: THE CURVEBALL APPROACH
articles.summary: The cost and complication of herbicide resistance is reshaping the way Prairie farmers manage their acres. It’s a frustrating problem that demands adaptation, typically in the form of integrated weed management (IWM), a customized, field-by-field strategy. One size does not fit all as farmers and agronomists tackle herbicide resistance with a multi-strategy approach.

articles.title: FUNDAMENTAL FARM SKILLS
articles.summary: Developed and delivered in collaboration with Farm Credit Canada and RBC, the Ontario Agricultural College (OAC) at the University of Guelph offers Foundations in Agricultural Management. The free online course is aimed at Canadian farmers, their families and ag industry professionals who wish to improve their business acumen, financial literacy and management skills. The non-credit, video seminar course is comprised of eight modules that take an average of 15 to 20 minutes each to work through.

articles.title: Strong yields mark start of Downs sorghum harvest
articles.summary: The sorghum harvest has started in pockets of the Darling Downs, with some districts recording standout yields of 6-7t/ha.

articles.title: Pulse Update: Chickpeas kick, fabas, lentils flat
articles.summary: Prices for chickpeas are rallying, while faba bean and lentil markets are trading sideways now that Australia’s 2025-26 winter pulse harvest is over.

articles.title: Mainland Australia’s winter-crop harvest nears end
articles.summary: Harvest on mainland Australia is rapidly winding down, with latest receival reports from major bulk handlers indicating a tail-off in deliveries.

articles.title: Australian chickpea, lentil exports surge in Nov
articles.summary: Australia exported 388,832 tonnes of chickpeas and 270,151t of lentils in November 2025, according to the latest data from the ABS.

articles.title: Russian wheat export pace rebounds into year’s end
articles.summary: A late-2025 run boosts the prospect of Russia's exporting 53-55Mt of grain to challenge the 53Mt shipped in 2024-25.

articles.title: Weekly rainfall update 13 January 2026 + outlook
articles.summary: Rain in coming days is forecast for tropical and far eastern Australia following TC Koji, which delivered some heavy falls and flooding in recent days.

articles.title: Daily Market Wire 14 January 2026
articles.summary: Talk of easing Canada China trade tension breathes life into canola, likely strengthens GM, as ag market lacks spark.

articles.title: GTA joins govt’s Trade Diversification Network
articles.summary: GTA has been accepted as a member of the Trade Diversification Network, strengthening its role in supporting the Australian grain industry as a leading exporter.

articles.title: GrainCorp, Zen-Noh sell Canadian JV to P&H
articles.summary: GrainCorp and Zen-Noh are selling their GrainsConnect investments in Canada to local major Parrish & Heimbecker.

articles.title: Bellata growers take NSW dryland wheat honours
articles.summary: A 9.2t/ha crop of Sundancer wheat has come out on top from a record 375 entries in the AgShows NSW 2025 Dryland Field Wheat Competition.

articles.title: ClimateAi targets key ag pain point with new GDD tool, embeds AI into workflows
articles.summary:
“Over the past year it has been clear how important it is to be able to roll out AI tools very quickly to our customers," says ClimateAi COO Will Kletter.

The post ClimateAi targets key ag pain point with new GDD tool, embeds AI into workflows appeared first on AgFunderNews.

articles.title: New human clinical study puts botanicals into the GLP-1 spotlight
articles.summary:
The research has generated significant interest from firms in food & supplements as consumers seek natural alternatives to GLP-1 drugs.

The post New human clinical study puts botanicals into the GLP-1 spotlight appeared first on AgFunderNews.

articles.title: Scaling out, not up: foodtech leaders rethink growth at Tufts event as capital dries up
articles.summary:
Lasso CEO Mike Messersmith: "When you start an email [to an investor] with, ‘Hey, I'm Mike from a plant-based meat company in Boston,’ it's like, ‘delete.’"

The post Scaling out, not up: foodtech leaders rethink growth at Tufts event as capital dries up appeared first on AgFunderNews.

articles.title: AgriFood Signals: Corteva & BP partner on biofuels, Grit Road launches second fund for midwest agtech
articles.summary:
Plus: The Protein Brewery raises funds for mycoprotein powder.

The post AgriFood Signals: Corteva & BP partner on biofuels, Grit Road launches second fund for midwest agtech appeared first on AgFunderNews.

articles.title: African agrifood VC ‘does not need to follow the Silicon Valley growth trajectory’
articles.summary:
Sector-specific funds are changing the conversation around VC investment into Africa's agrifood landscape, says CRAF's managing partner.

The post African agrifood VC ‘does not need to follow the Silicon Valley growth trajectory’ appeared first on AgFunderNews.

articles.title: New US dietary guidelines elevate meat and full-fat dairy, ignite protein debate: ‘Most Americans already eat plenty’
articles.summary:
Americans are now advised to eat 1.2-1.6g protein per kg of bodyweight per day vs the current RDA of 0.8g in the 2025-30 dietary guidelines.

The post New US dietary guidelines elevate meat and full-fat dairy, ignite protein debate: ‘Most Americans already eat plenty’ appeared first on AgFu

articles.title: Kubota shows autonomous M5 Narrow tractor and ‘Transformer’ robot concept at CES 2026
articles.summary: Kubota used CES 2026 in Las Vegas (US) to preview two agriculture-focused innovations: a factory-integrated autonomous version of its M5 Narrow specialty tractor, and a concept “Transformer” platform robot (KVPR) designed to morph into different machine formats via interchangeable attachments.

articles.title: Crop conditions prove crucial for tomato harvest robots in greenhouse trials
articles.summary: Harvest robots are proving capable of cutting truss tomatoes, although crop characteristics and growing conditions are strongly decisive for how successfully and how quickly they perform. During the NPPL-R Horticulture annual event in Bunnik, two tomato harvesting robots were presented and tested in cocktail tomato crops. Both systems have their own unique approach and points […]

articles.title: Monarch Tractors restarts with shift from own tractor to autonomy software
articles.summary: US manufacturer Monarch Tractor is making a restart after a major restructuring. Operating under the name Zimeno Inc., the company is largely discontinuing the production, sales and service of its own electric tractors and will instead focus on software, autonomy and AI solutions for other machinery manufacturers.
